subject: Re: [junit] After I write my first testcase, I write 15 class make it run:-
msgSnippet: ... Since you ve already written all that code, I recommend you start by testing your model code, which is everything /outside/ the GUI. Once you have all
messageBody:
isaachanstar wrote:
> I am a newer to junit. I try to write a simulate elevator program with
> GUI. After I write my first testcase, I write 15 class make it run,
> inculde GUI interface and its simple implement.
> Any advise? How to write a suitable testcase? Thanks
>
> (Anyhow, TDD is magic to me! It's happy to call a nonexistent method
> first, and implement it second.)

Since you've already written all that code, I recommend you start by
testing your "model" code, which is everything /outside/ the GUI.

Once you have all that tested, you can start trying to test the code in
the GUI, too.

As for how to write a suitable test case, start with the methods that
return values, since they are easiest to test.

Good luck.
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com
2005 Gordon Pask Award Winner for contribution to Agile practice
Author, JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
